title: Who was Robert Badinter, the most important Frenchman of whom you never heard?

quotes: as the man who abolished the death penalty in 1981.
There had been talk of abolishing the capital punishment since the French Revolution.
Already in 1791, deputies had debated on whether to include it in the country’s first criminal code.
In the following century, French novelist Victor Hugo would take up the baton, devoting two novels to the subject, The Last Day of a Condemned Man (1829) and Claude Gueux (1834).

In 1977, his defence of Patrick Henry, who is convicted for the kidnapping and murder of 7-year-old Philippe Bertrand, is seen as a turning point in the history of the abolition of the death penalty.
On 14 February, Emmanual Macron described him as ‘a soul crying out, a force wrenching life from the clutch of death.’
until becoming Justice Minister under President François Mittérand in 1981.
On 18 September of that year, the French parliament ended capital punishment, with 363 votes against 117.
